questions.text: Based on the properties of viruses, which of the following sentences is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: A virus can either possess DNA or RNA, but never both.

options.label: B
options.text: All animal viruses are spherical in shape.

options.label: C
options.text: Viruses are obligate intracellular and can only replicate inside a host cell.

options.label: D
options.text: All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.

questions.correct_answer: B. All animal viruses are spherical in shape.
questions.explanation:
General properties of viruses

Characteristics

  • They do not have a cellular organisation.
  • Obligate intracellular parasites - cannot replicate outside a host. (Option C)
  • Lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis.
  • Multiply via a complex process.
  • They cannot be cultured in cell-free culture media but can grow in embryonated eggs or tissue culture.
  • They can pass through filters.

Morphology

  • All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.
  • Either possess DNA or RNA but never both. (Option A)
  • Nucleic acid is enclosed by a protein capsid, which may or may not be enclosed by a lipid envelope. (Option D)

Shape
  • Most are spherical. (Option B)
  • Some are irregular and pleomorphic
  • Different shapes of animal viruses are
    • Rabies virus - bullet-shaped
    • Ebola virus - filamentous
    • Pox virus - brick shaped
    • Tobacco mosaic virus - rod-shaped

Size

Ranges from 300 nm - Poxvirus to 20 nm - Parvovirus

questions.text: Based on the image given below, which of the following statements is true regarding the symmetry of the viruses? Poxvirus has a symmetry similar to structure A Adenovirus has a symmetry similar to structure B Rhabdovirus has a symmetry similar to structure A Structure B has two types of capsomers The helical tube in structure A is rigid in all viruses with a similar structure.
questions.explanation:
Symmetry of virus

Icosahedral

Helical

Complex

  • Polygon with 12 vertices and 20 sides
  • Consist of two types of capsomer (Statement 4)
  • Structure is rigid
  • All DNA viruses have this symmetry except for Poxvirus
  • Eg
    • Adenovirus (Statement 2)
    • Herpesvirus
    • Hepadnavirus
    • Papovavirus
  • Capsomers are coiled around the nucleic acid in the form of a spiral or helix.
  • The tube is rigid in tobacco mosaic virus but flexible in animal virus (Statement 5)
  • Seen in a few RNA viruses
  • Eg
    • Myxoviruses
    • Rhabdovirus (Statement 3)
    • Filovirus
  • Complex symmetry is seen in a few viruses, such as Poxvirus (Statement 1)

questions.text: A 34-year-old researcher accidentally exposes a viral sample to alcohol during a lab procedure. He recalls that alcohol can disrupt certain viral structures. Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure of viral envelopes and capsids?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemagglutinin is a protein subunit found exclusively in non-enveloped viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-enveloped viruses are more alcohol labile than enveloped viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: Viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane.

options.label: D
options.text: Capsid in enveloped viruses gives the virus its pleomorphic shape.

questions.correct_answer: C. Viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane.
questions.explanation:
STRUCTURE OF VIRUS

CAPSID: Protein coat surrounding the viral nucleic acid.
  • It is composed of small morphological units called capsomeres
  • The polypeptide molecules are arranged symmetrically
  • It forms an impenetrable shell around the nucleic core
  • It is adsorbed by the host cell membrane readily, thus introducing the viral genome into the host

ENVELOPED: Viral capsid is surrounded by a lipid membrane
  • It is derived from the host cell membrane by viral progeny during the budding process (Option C)
  • They have protein subunits that project on the envelope surface (Peplomers), which are viral-coded
  • The shape of the virus depends on the lipid envelope. (Option D)
  • Example (Option A)
    • Influenza virus has two types of peplomers:
      • Hemagglutinin: Triangular spike.
      • Neuraminidase: Mushroom-shaped structure.
  • Functions:
    • Confers chemical, antigenic, and biological properties.
    • Facilitates attachment to host cell surfaces.
    • Aids in processes such as hemagglutination
  • Enveloped viruses are sensitive to lipid solvents, including Ether, Chloroform and Bile salts.
  • Specific neutralisation of virus infectivity is mediated by antibodies targeting surface antigens.
  • Some viruses may have unique structural features, e.g., fibrils protruding from the vertices of adenovirus particles.

NON-ENVELOPED: Lack the lipid membrane, and viral capsid is naked
  • They lack the lipid membrane
  • More resistant to lipid solvents (Option B)
  • The shape of the virus depends on the shape of the capsid (Option D)

Most viruses are enveloped except:

  • Naked DNA viruses: Parvovirus, Papavovirus and Adenovirus
  • Naked RNA viruses: Picornaviruses, reovirus, calicivirus, astroviridae, Hep A and Hep E

questions.text: Three patients come to the hospital, each presenting with three different infectious diseases. Patient A has Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Patient B has Potato spindle tuber viroid disease. Patient C has an Influenza type B infection. Which option correctly describes the composition of each pathogen?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient A: Nucleic acids only Patient B: Protein and nucleic acids Patient C: RNA only

options.label: B
options.text: Patient A: Infectious protein only Patient B: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid Patient C: Enveloped RNA

options.label: C
options.text: Patient A: Enveloped RNA Patient B: Infectious protein only Patient C: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid

options.label: D
options.text: Patient A: Enveloped RNA Patient B: RNA only Patient C: Protein and nucleic acids

questions.correct_answer: B. Patient A: Infectious protein only Patient B: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid Patient C: Enveloped RNA
questions.explanation:
VIRUS

VIROID

PRION

Definition

Infectious agent composed of nucleic acid enclosed in a protein coat with or without a lipid envelope. (Patient C)

Infectious molecule composed of small, circular ssRNA without a capsid. (Patient B)

Infectious agent, composed of only infectious proteins.

(Patient A)

Composition

DNA/RNA + protein +/- Lipid.

RNA only.

Protein only.

Replication

Replicates using host cellular machinery

Replicates using host cellular machinery.

Replicates by inducing protein misfolding in the host.

Stability

Stability varies

Enveloped viruses are sensitive to lipid solvents, while non-enveloped are more resistant.

Resistant to heat and organic solvent.

Resistant to heat and proteolytic enzymes and heat, it can remain infectious for years.

Examples

Influenza virus, Poxvirus, Reovirus

Potato spindle tuber viroid,

Plant diseases

Creutzfeldt-jakob disease

Virion: Complete virus particle that includes a genome and a protein coat, which exists outside of host cells, representing one of the physical forms of a virus during a specific phase of its replication cycle.

questions.text: Identify the mismatched pair of viruses and their site of viral replication. Adenovirus - Cytosol Poxvirus - Cytosol Parvovirus - Nucleus HIV - Mixed
Based on the steps of viral replication, label the following diagram

options.label: A
options.text: A - Attachment, B - Translation, C- Transcription, D- budding

options.label: B
options.text: A - Penetration, B - Translation, C- Transcription, D- budding

options.label: C
options.text: A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation

options.label: D
options.text: A - Attachment, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D- Maturation

questions.correct_answer: C. A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation
questions.explanation:
VIRAL REPLICATION

Attachment:

  • Receptor interaction between viral surface antigen and host cell surface antigens.
  • HIV: Viral surface gp120 binds to CD 24 on host cells.
  • Influenza: Viral hemagglutinin binds to glycoprotein receptors on respiratory epithelium

Penetration: Viral particle enters the host cells via -

  • Phagocytosis/viropexis (receptor mediated endocytosis occurs)
  • Membrane fusion (some enveloped viruses enter via fusion of their membrane with the host cell membrane; thus, only the nucleocapsid enters).
  • Injection of nucleic acid by bacteriophages.

Uncoating: Host cell lysosomal enzymes separate the viral capsid and nucleic acid.

Biosynthesis

  • Nucleic acid replication
    • DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus except for the Pox virus, which replicates in the cytosol.
    • RNA viruses replicate within the cytosol except retroviruses and orthomyxoviruses
  • Transcription of Viral nucleic material
    • DNA viruses: DNA is transcribed into RNA in the mRNA in the cytosol.
    • + sense RNA viruses: Directly replicated/transcribed or translated
    • - sense RNA viruses: Transcribed into +ve sense RNA first, which is then replicated
    • dsRNA viruses
      • +ve strand is directly replicated/transcribed or translated.
      • -ve strand is transcribed into +ve sense RNA first.
      • Both strands can serve as templates for complementary strands
    • In retroviruses, reverse transcription converts viral single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) into double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), which is then integrated into the host genome.
  • Translation: Viral RNA is translated to form viral protein, which can be packed into progeny viruses.

Assembly: Viral nucleic acid and protein are packed together to form new viral progeny.

  • DNA viruses are assembled in the nucleus except Poxvirus and Hepadnavirus.
  • RNA viruses are assembled in the cytosol.

Maturation: The daughter virions mature in the nucleus/cytosol/membranes (Golgi Apparatus or endoplasmic reticulum or plasma membrane.

RELEASE

  • Lysis of cells: Usually occurs in non-enveloped viruses and bacteriophages.
  • Budding: occurs in enveloped viruses.
    • During budding, the virus acquires a part of the host membrane, leading to envelope formation.

questions.text: A virology lab receives samples from a patient with a suspected viral infection presenting with fever, cough, and body aches. Testing confirms the presence of an RNA virus. Which of the following is an example of an RNA virus?
questions.explanation:
DNA virus

RNA virus

Herpesviridae:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1, HSV-2)
  • Varicella-zoster virus
  • Epstein-Barr virus (Option A)
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • HHV-6,7,8

Hepadnaviridae:

  • Hepatitis B virus

Parvoviridae:

  • Parvovirus B19

Papovaviridae:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • JC virus (Option B)
  • BK virus

Poxviridae:

  • Variola virus (smallpox)
  • Molluscum contagiosum virus

Adenoviridae:

  • Human adenovirus (Option C)

Bacteriophage

Picornaviridae:

  • Poliovirus
  • Coxsackievirus
  • Rhinovirus
  • Hepatitis A virus
  • Enterovirus

Caliciviridae:

  • Hepatitis E virus

Togaviridae:

  • Rubella virus
  • Eastern equine encephalitis virus
  • Western equine encephalitis virus

Flaviviridae:

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Hepatitis C virus
  • West Nile virus

Coronaviridae:

  • SARS-CoV
  • MERS-CoV
  • SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19)

Rhabdoviridae:

  • Rabies virus

Filoviridae:

  • Ebola virus

Paramyxoviridae:

  • Measles virus
  • Mumps virus
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
  • Nipah virus
  • Parainfluenza virus

Orthomyxoviridae:

  • Influenza viruses (A, B, C, D)

Bunyaviridae

Arenaviridae

Reoviridae:

  • Rotavirus
  • Reovirus
  • Colorado tick fever virus

Retroviridae:

  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is diagnosed with a viral infection after presenting with symptoms such as fever, chills, and body aches. Laboratory analysis reveals a helical virus with a negative-sense RNA genome. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
During the production of a viral vaccine using embryonated hen’s eggs, which site is specifically utilised for the cultivation of yellow fever virus?
Which of the following structures can be used to cultivate the Japanese encephalitis virus?
A researcher needs to isolate a virus using a cell line that can divide a maximum of 10 to 50 times before senescence. Which of the following cell lines should they choose?
questions.explanation:
Primary Cell Lines

Secondary/Diploid

Cell Lines

Continuous Cell Lines

5-10 divisions

(Limited growth capacity)

10-50 divisions

Indefinite growth

(Continuous divisions)

Maintain a diploid karyotype

Maintain a diploid karyotype

Altered haploid chromosomes
  • Monkey kidney cell line (for myxoviruses, enteroviruses, adenoviruses).
  • Human amnion cell line.
  • Chick embryo cell line.
  • Human fibroblast cell line (CMV)
  • MRC-5 and WI-38

(Used for viral vaccines like rabies, chickenpox, and MMR, and virus isolation such as HSV)
  • HeLa cell line (human cervical carcinoma)
  • HEp-2 cell line (for RSV, adenoviruses, HSV)
  • KB cell line (human nasopharynx carcinoma)
  • McCoy cell line (for virus isolation and Chlamydia)
  • Vero cell line (for rabies vaccine production).
  • BHK cell line (baby hamster kidney).

questions.text: A patient’s cell culture exhibits distinct cytopathic effects characterised by the formation of syncytia (multinucleated giant cells). Based on these observations, which virus is most likely responsible for the infection?

A 45-year-old patient presents with neurological symptoms, and a brain biopsy is performed, revealing the presence of inclusion bodies as shown in the image. What are these inclusion bodies commonly referred to as?

A new respiratory virus has emerged in a rural community, with early reports indicating a high transmission rate and increased hospitalisations. Public health officials must evaluate the virus's infectivity to implement effective control measures. Which of the following assays is most appropriate for quantifying the virus's infectivity?
questions.explanation:
Assay

Description

Endpoint assay

They are used for infectivity titration, for example, animal mortality, hemagglutinin production in allantoic fluid, and the appearance of cytopathic effects (CPE) in cell cultures.

Plaque assay

Agar is poured over a viral specimen on a cell line, revealing visible plaques (localised focus) of infected cells. The number of plaques corresponds to the infective virions.

Pox assay

Assessed by counting the number of pocks formed on the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) from the appropriate viral inocula (Eg, Vaccinia)

questions.text: Match the following interferons with their respective sources, 1. Alpha interferon a. Fibroblasts 2. Beta interferon b. T-lymphocytes 3. Gamma interferon c. Leucocytes

Glycoprotein

Th1 (T-helper type 1) lymphocytes

Function

  • Antiviral properties
  • Antiviral properties
  • Used for multiple sclerosis.
  • Immunomodulatory and anti-proliferative (granuloma formation).
  • Treatment of chronic granulomatous disease.
